For the Impatient

If you already know Docker:

$ docker logs mybox
...
+----------------------------+
|  Device Key:  12345678     |

+----------------------------+

Replace /path/to/data with the path you want to store your data. Enter the Device Key 12345678 to 1Album app:

That’s it! Now your photos and videos will be backed up to this blackbox.

About the name "Blackbox"

To most people, the name "blackbox" relates to black boxes on airplanes immediately. Also known as flight recorders, they record everything about the flight, and their main job is to make sure that its data will not be damaged or lost no matter what happens.

Photos and videos are precious memories to our life that cannot be retaken. We also want to keep them forever no matter what happens. So we name our 1Album storage server "blackbox" and appoint it to be our life recorder.

Install Blackbox On Linux

Step 1: Install Docker

1Album Blackbox is distributed as a Docker Image. Your system must have Docker installed before you can install blackbox. The installation procedure varies among Linux distributions, please reference the official Docker Engine installation guide for details. On Ubuntu 16.04, the easist way to install Docker is:

$ sudo apt-get install docker.io

Step 2: Install Blackbox

You can download 1Album Blackbox with the following command:

$ docker pull 1album/blackbox

Downloading:

After download is completed, use docker images to list downloaded images:

Step 3: First Launch

Use the following command to launch 1Album Blackbox for the first time:

$ docker run -itd \
         -v /path/to/data:/data \
         --name mybox \
         1album/blackbox

The most important argument is -v, it links /data volume to local folder /path/to/data on your system. 1Album Blackbox stores everything in /data volume. You must link it to a local folder before starting the blackbox. Please do not manually alter the content in this folder, otherwise your data inside the blackbox may be damaged or lost.

Besides /data, there are three optional volumes that can be configured. /export is for exporting data out of the blackbox, and /import is for importing data back in. /cache is for storing temporarily files such as thumbnail images. The example below links all of them to local folders:

$ docker run -itd \
         -v /path/to/data:/data \
         -v /path/to/cache:/cache \
         -v /path/to/import:/import \
         -v /path/to/export:/export \
         --name mybox \
         1album/blackbox

After the docker run command, you can use docker ps command to list the running Docker containers. The last colume shows the name you specified with the --name argument previously.

Step 4: Link Account

You must add the blackbox to your account to start using it. First, obtain the Device Key from the log using the following command. mybox is what you specified with the --name argument previously:

$ docker logs mybox

You can find your Device Key in the output:

Then open 1Album app and enter the Device Key as below:

Now this blackbox will work for you. Your account name is also printed in the blackbox log:

Install Blackbox On Mac OSX

Step 1: Install Docker

1Album Blackbox is distributed as a Docker Image. Your system must have Docker installed before you can install blackbox. To install Docker, download Docker Toolbox here and install it. Please reference Docker Toolbox installation guide for detail instructions.

After installation, click the Kitematic icon to start Docker:

A login page shows up. Login is optional, you can just click the SKIP FOR NOW button:

After the login page, Kitematic home page shows up:

Step 2: Install Blackbox

Enter 1album in the search box to search for 1Album Blackbox, then click the CREATE button to download and install it:

Downloading:

After download is completed, this error message shows up. Don’t worry, this is because we haven’t setup /data volume yet.

Step 3: First Launch

1Album Blackbox stores everything in /data volume. You must associate it to a local folder before starting the blackbox. Open Seetings -> Volumes page, then click the CHANGE button corresponding to the /data volume:

Select any folder you want. Note that you must not manually alter the content in this folder, otherwise your data inside the blackbox may be damaged or lost.

After a folder is selected, it is listed next to the /data volume:

Besides /data, there are three optional volumes that can be configured. /export is for exporting data out of the blackbox, and /import is for importing data back in. /cache is for storing temporarily files such as thumbnail images.

Click HOME when you’re done. The blackbox is now started:

Step 4: Link Account

You must add the blackbox to your account to start using it. First, write down the Device Key:

Then open 1Album app and enter the Device Key as below:

Now this blackbox will work for you. Your account name is also listed on the blackbox console:

Enter Blackbox Shell

1Album Blackbox is designed to run autonomously, so entering its command shell is not necessary. Nonetheless, there are advanced features that are available only through the command shell. The following describes how to enter the command shell on each of the operating systems. For a list of commands available in the shell, please reference the Blackbox Commands page.

Mac OSX

First please make sure that the blackbox is running. The command shell is available only when the blackbox is running. Now click the DOCKER CLI button in the lower left corner:

The OSX terminal window pops up. Enter docker attach blackbox then hit Enter twice. Once you see the blackbox> prompt, you are in the command shell. If there are multiple blackboxes installed, you need to put the name shown in the Kitematic interface after attach.

Hit Ctrl-P then Ctrl-Q to detach from the command shell and back to OSX shell. You can also close the terminal window directly without hitting Ctrl-P Ctrl-Q, the shell will be detached automatically.

Windows

First please make sure that the blackbox is running. The command shell is available only when the blackbox is running. Now click the DOCKER CLI button in the lower left corner:

The Windows terminal window pops up. Enter docker attach blackbox then hit Enter twice. Once you see the blackbox> prompt, you are in the command shell. If there are multiple blackboxes installed, you need to put the name shown in the Kitematic interface after attach.

Hit Ctrl-P then Ctrl-Q to detach from the command shell and back to Windows shell. You can also close the terminal window directly without hitting Ctrl-P Ctrl-Q, the shell will be detached automatically.

Linux

Use the following command to enter the blackbox shell. You usually need to press Enter twice to see the blackbox> prompt. Once you see the prompt, you are in the shell. mybox below is what you specified with the --name argument when you setup this blackbox:

$ docker attach mybox

Hit Ctrl-P then Ctrl-Q to detach from the command shell and back to Linux shell. You can also close the terminal window directly without hitting Ctrl-P Ctrl-Q, the shell will be detached automatically.

Synology NAS

First please make sure that the blackbox is running. The command shell is available only when the blackbox is running. Now click the Details button:

The details dialog pops up. Switch to the Terminal tab, and hit Enter in the black area. Once you see the blackbox> prompt, you are in the blackbox shell. Note that the current Safari browser on OSX cannot open this terminal page. Please use Chrome or Firefox on OSX instead. Windows browsers work fine.

Hit Ctrl-P then Ctrl-Q to detach from the command shell. The black area becomes gray, and you need to re-open this dialog box if you want to enter the command shell again. You can also close the dialog window directly without hitting Ctrl-P Ctrl-Q, the shell will be detached automatically.

Install Blackbox On Synology NAS

Step 1: Install Docker

1Album Blackbox is distributed as a Docker Image. You must install Docker on your Synology NAS before installing blackbox. Many Synology NAS models support this, but it seems limited to those with a “+” symbol at the end of its model number. For a full list of supported models, please check the bottom of the Synology Docker Package page.

To install Docker, login to your Synology NAS, open Package Center on the desktop and search for Docker, then click the Install button. If you cannot find Docker, your model does not support it.

When installation is done, Docker is listed in the installed packages:

Docker is also listed in the main menu. Click to open it:

This is the main page of Docker on Synology NAS:

Step 2: Install Blackbox

Switch to Registry tab on the left, then enter 1album in the search box to search for 1Album Blackbox.

Selected the item then click Download button to download:

When download is in progress, the icon on the right is animated:

When download is completed, the icon will stop animating, and a notification message will be posted:

Step 3: First Launch

Switch to the ‘Image’ tab on the left, select 1Album Blackbox image, then click Launch button to launch it:

A settings dialog shows up. Click Advanced Settings in the dialog box:

The Enable auto restart function circled below can restart the blacbox automatically should it encounter an unexpected error and quite. We recommand you to enable it:

Now switch to the Volume tab. 1Album Blackbox stores everything in /data volume. You must associate it to a local folder before starting the blackbox. You do that by click the Add Folder button below:

Select any folder you want, or click Create Folder button to create a new one. Note that you must not manually alter the content in this folder, otherwise your data inside the blackbox may be damaged or lost. Click the Select button when you’re done.

After a local folder is selected, enter /data (all lowercase) in the Mount path field. Now the /data volume is configured.

Besides /data, there are three optional volumes that can be configured. /export is for exporting data out of the blackbox, and /import is for importing data back in. /cache is for storing temporarily files such as thumbnail images. In the example below, each of the volumes is linked to a local folder in NAS. Click OK when you’re done:

We are back to the settings dialog. Click Next:

Make sure at least the /data volume is linked to a local folder, then click Apply:

Step 4: Link Account

You must add the blackbox to your account to start using it. First switch to Container tab on the left, select the running blackbox, then click the Details button:

Switch to the Log page in the detail dialog. You can find the Device Key inside:

Then open 1Album app and enter the Device Key as below:

Now this blackbox will work for you. Your account name is also printed in the blackbox log. This log page does not refresh automatically, you need to click the little refresh button at the lower right corner to refresh:

Install Blackbox On Windows

Step 1: Install Docker

1Album Blackbox is distributed as a Docker Image. Your system must have Docker installed before you can install blackbox. To install Docker, download Docker Toolbox here and install it. Please reference Docker Toolbox installation guide for detail instructions. Note that your system must have 64-bit version Windows with a CPU that supports virtualization technology, which means older or lower end systems probably won’t work. Please check Windows system requirements for details.

After installation, click the Kitematic icon to start Docker:

item.description: Backing up photos is very fast with peer-to-peer connections link directly from your phone to your blackbox. It is especially so when they are in the same local network.
